docs.title: NanoCut Control Manual
docs.text: Welcome to the NanoCut Control manual!

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: NanoCut Control is a CNC control application for plasma cutting machines running NanoCut firmware.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Reliable control based on the grbl protocol
  • Real-time machine control
  • DXF file import and processing
  • G-code generation supporting Torch Height Control

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: New to NanoCut Control? Follow the Getting Started guide for a step-by-step walkthrough of your first cutting job.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
CAM View is where you design toolpaths from DXF files. Here you import parts, configure cutting tools, create operations, arrange parts on the material sheet, and generate G-code for the controller.

Switch to CAM View by pressing Tab from Control View.

docs.title: Importing a DXF
docs.text: Open File > Import Part (or use the import button in the left pane) to load a DXF file.

docs.title: DXF Importer Dialog
docs.text:
When importing, you can configure:

  • Quality (8--16): Controls curve approximation resolution. Higher values produce smoother curves with more line segments.
  • Scale factor: Multiplier applied to the imported geometry.
  • Unit auto-detection: The importer reads the DXF header to determine whether the file uses millimeters or inches and converts accordingly.

docs.title: Supported Geometry
docs.text:
The importer handles the following DXF entities:

  • Lines
  • Arcs
  • Circles
  • Polylines (including bulge arcs)
  • Splines
  • Ellipses

docs.title: Layer Filtering
docs.text: Layers named "Construction" and entities with non-continuous linetypes are automatically skipped during import.

docs.title: Parts Panel (Left Pane)
docs.text:
The left pane shows a tree view of all imported parts.

  • Master parts and duplicates: When you duplicate a part, the copy is linked to the master. Changes to the master propagate to duplicates.
  • Layer visibility: Toggle individual layers on or off.
  • Right-click context menu: Delete parts, view properties.
  • Properties window: Shows dimensions, path count, vertex count, scale, rotation angle, and simplification settings.

docs.title: Job Options
docs.text:
Configure the cutting job parameters:

  • Material size: Set the width and height of your sheet metal. This defines the working area shown in the viewport.
  • Origin corner: Choose which corner of the material corresponds to the work zero position. Four options are available (one for each corner).

docs.title: Tool Library
docs.text: The Tool Library stores your cutting tool definitions. Each tool represents a set of plasma cutting parameters for a specific material and thickness.

docs.title: Creating and Editing Tools
docs.text:
Each tool has the following parameters:

Parameter Description Tool name A descriptive name (e.g., "3mm Mild Steel") Pierce height Z height during the initial pierce. Set higher than cut height to protect the torch from blowback. Pierce delay Time in seconds to wait after firing the torch before moving. Allows the arc to fully penetrate the material. Cut height Z height maintained during cutting. Critical for cut quality. Kerf width Width of material removed by the plasma arc. Used for offset compensation so finished parts match the design dimensions. Feed rate Cutting speed. Too fast causes dross on the bottom; too slow causes excessive heat and wider kerf. THC target voltage Arc voltage setpoint for Torch Height Control. THC adjusts the torch height during cutting to maintain this voltage, which corresponds to a consistent cut height.

docs.title: Tool Operations
docs.text: Operations connect tools to DXF layers, defining how each layer gets cut.

docs.title: Creating an Operation
docs.text:
1. Select a tool from the Tool Library.
  2. Select a layer from the imported parts.
  3. Configure lead-in length and lead-out length. These control the approach and exit paths that prevent the pierce from damaging the cut edge. Default is 1.5x the tool's kerf width.

docs.title: Managing Operations
docs.text:
• Enable/disable: Toggle operations on or off without deleting them.
  • Operations list: All operations appear in the left pane. The order determines the cutting sequence.

docs.title: Manual Positioning
docs.text:
Switch to Nesting Tool mode to move parts:

  • Drag parts to reposition them on the material sheet.
  • Ctrl+scroll on a selected part to rotate it in 5-degree increments.
  • Shift+scroll on a selected part to scale it.

docs.title: Automatic Nesting
docs.text: Press the Arrange button to run automatic nesting optimization. This positions parts to minimize material waste.

docs.title: Save G-code to File
docs.text: Use File > Save GCode to write the generated toolpath to a .nc or .gcode file for later use or transfer to another machine.

docs.title: Send to Controller
docs.text: Press Send to Controller to transfer the G-code directly to the machine. This automatically switches to Control View so you can run the job.

docs.title: View Controls
docs.text: Control Action Right-click drag Pan the view Scroll wheel Zoom in/out Contour Tool Select and edit contours Nesting Tool Select, move, rotate, and scale parts

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Control View is where you operate the CNC plasma cutter. Here you jog the machine, set work coordinates, run G-code programs, and monitor cutting in real time.

Switch to Control View by pressing Tab from CAM View.

docs.title: The DRO (Digital Readout) Pane
docs.text: The DRO displays the current machine position across three axes: X, Y, and Z.

docs.title: Coordinate Display
docs.text:
Each axis shows two numbers:

  • Large number -- Work Coordinate (WCS): Position relative to your work zero. This is the coordinate system you set with Zero X / Zero Y.
  • Small number -- Machine Coordinate (MCS): Absolute position relative to the machine home. This never changes unless you re-home.

docs.title: Status Line
docs.text:
Below the coordinates, four readouts show real-time cutting data:

Readout Description FEED Current feed rate (mm/min or in/min) ARC Current arc voltage reading from the plasma cutter SET THC voltage setpoint (the target voltage for torch height control) RUN Elapsed run time for the current program

docs.title: Visual Indicators
docs.text:
• The DRO background turns red when the torch is firing.
  • The ARC readout changes color to indicate arc_ok status (whether the plasma arc has transferred to the workpiece).

docs.title: The THC Widget
docs.text: Below the DRO is a row of 6 buttons for adjusting the torch height in real time during cutting.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The buttons apply a voltage offset to the THC target:

Button Offset -4 Decrease target by 4V -1.5 Decrease target by 1.5V -0.5 Decrease target by 0.5V Center Displays current offset (e.g., "+2.0") +0.5 Increase target by 0.5V +1.5 Increase target by 1.5V +4 Increase target by 4V
  • Offset range: -12V to +12V
  • Effective voltage = base THC target + offset (clamped to 0--250V)
  • Adjustments only take effect while the torch is firing.

Use this to fine-tune cut height during a job if you notice the torch is too high or too low.

docs.title: The HMI (Control Buttons) Pane
docs.text:
The HMI pane provides direct machine control buttons:

Button Description Zero X Sets the X work coordinate to zero at the current position Zero Y Sets the Y work coordinate to zero at the current position Touch Probes the material surface height (dry run, no torch fire). Performs a touch-off cycle to establish Z zero. Retract Raises the torch to Z=0 Fit Zooms the viewport to show all loaded G-code Clean Clears highlight paths from the view (e.g., arc-not-ok highlights) Wpos Rapid move to the work position origin (X0 Y0) Park Returns the machine to home position (machine coordinates) Home Initiates the homing cycle (finds limit switches) Test Run Runs the loaded G-code as a dry run -- probes the surface but does not fire the torch. Use this to verify the path before cutting. Run Executes the loaded G-code with the torch firing Abort Stops the current operation immediately

docs.title: Machine Plane Display
docs.text:
The main viewport shows a top-down view of the machine working area:

  • Blue rectangle -- Full machine working area (defined by machine extents).
  • Green rectangle -- Safe cutting zone (cuttable extents). Programs that extend outside this area will be rejected.
  • Torch pointer -- A circle that follows the real-time machine position.

docs.title: View Controls
docs.text: Control Action Right-click drag Pan the view Scroll wheel Zoom in/out Fit button Zoom to show all G-code

docs.title: Waypoint Navigation
docs.text: Click anywhere on the machine plane to navigate the torch to that position. A confirmation dialog will appear before the machine moves.

docs.title: Jump-In Feature
docs.text:
Ctrl+left-click on a G-code contour to start the program from that specific contour. All contours before the clicked one are skipped. This is useful when:

  • A cut failed partway through a job and you want to resume from a specific part.
  • You only need to re-cut certain contours.

docs.title: Reverse Path
docs.text: Ctrl+right-click on a contour to reverse its cutting direction. This is useful when a cut fails mid-contour and you want to restart from the other end.

docs.title: Loading G-code
docs.text: Load a G-code file via File > Open, or receive it directly from CAM View using Send to Controller.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before using NanoCut Control, you need:

  • A CNC plasma cutting machine with a compatible grbl controller
  • NanoCut firmware flashed on the controller
  • A USB connection between the controller and your computer
  • A DXF file to cut (or you can use any DXF editor to create one)

docs.title: A Note on Units
docs.text: NanoCut Control uses metric units (millimeters) by default. If you need imperial units (inches), the application must be recompiled with the USE_INCH_DEFAULTS flag.

docs.title: First Launch
docs.text:
1. Connect your CNC controller to the computer via USB.
  2. Launch NanoCut Control. The application opens in Control View by default.
  3. Home the machine by pressing the Home button. This establishes the machine's coordinate system by finding the limit switches.

docs.title: Quick Workflow Overview
docs.text: A typical cutting job follows these steps:

docs.title: 1. Switch to CAM View
docs.text: Press Tab to switch to CAM View, the toolpath design workspace.

docs.title: 2. Import a DXF File
docs.text: Use File > Import Part (or the import button in the left pane) to load your DXF file. The importer will auto-detect units and convert geometry.

docs.title: 3. Set Up Job Options
docs.text: Configure the material size (width and height) to match your sheet metal. Choose the origin corner to match your work zero location.

docs.title: 4. Create a Tool
docs.text:
Open the Tool Library and create a tool with the correct plasma parameters for your material:

  • Pierce height -- Z height during the initial pierce
  • Pierce delay -- time to wait for the pierce to complete
  • Cut height -- Z height during cutting
  • Feed rate -- cutting speed
  • Kerf width -- width of material removed by the plasma arc
  • THC target voltage -- arc voltage setpoint for Torch Height Control

docs.title: 5. Create a Tool Operation
docs.text: Create an operation that assigns your tool to a DXF layer. Configure lead-in and lead-out lengths (defaults to 1.5x kerf width).

docs.title: 6. Arrange Parts on the Material
docs.text: Position parts on the sheet using the Nesting Tool. Drag parts to move them, use Ctrl+scroll to rotate (5-degree increments), or press Arrange for automatic nesting.

docs.title: 7. Send to Controller
docs.text: Use File > Save GCode to export a G-code file, or use Send to Controller to transfer the program directly and switch to Control View.

docs.title: 8. Switch to Control View
docs.text: Press Tab to return to Control View (or it switches automatically after Send to Controller).

docs.title: 9. Home, Touch Off, Run
docs.text:
1. Home the machine if not already done.
  2. Jog to your desired work zero and press Zero X / Zero Y.
  3. Press Touch to probe the material surface height.
  4. Press Test Run to verify the path without firing the torch.
  5. Press Run to cut the part.

docs.title: Essential Shortcuts
docs.text:
Shortcut Action Tab Switch between CAM View and Control View Escape Abort current operation Arrow keys Jog the machine (hold to move) Ctrl+Arrow keys Precise jog (fixed distance) Ctrl+click Jump-in: start program from a specific contour

See the full Keyboard Shortcuts reference for more.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: NanoCut Control requires the following dependencies:

docs.title: Required Dependencies
docs.text:
• Git (for version information and dependency fetching)
  • CMake 3.21+
  • C++20 compatible compiler (GCC 11+, Clang 14+, MSVC 2022+)
  • OpenGL development libraries
  • GLFW development libraries

docs.title: Building from Source
docs.text: Building is similar for all platforms thanks to CMake. An installation step is provided via CMake, which will install the executable, themes, and fonts.

docs.title: Pre-requisites
docs.text: Downloading/updating is done with Git. Windows users can run winget install Git.Git, then restart your terminal.

docs.title: First-time setup
docs.text:
Clone the repository and check out the desired release:

git clone https://github.com/nwjnilsson/nanocut-control.git
cd nanocut-control
git checkout v1.0.0

docs.title: Updating
docs.text:
Fetch the latest tags and update the source:

git fetch --tags
git checkout latest

I don't recommend staying on main.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
A powershell helper script is provided to help Windows users build from source. The script will check for CMake, Ninja, and Visual Studio Build Tools — offering to install any that are missing via winget — then configure, build, and install the executable to bin\NanoCut.exe inside the repository.

Simply run:

.\scripts\build-windows.ps1

If you already have vcpkg, you can point to it with e.g -VcpkgPath C:\vcpkg

docs.title: NixOS
docs.text:
1. A shell.nix is provided, enter the environment:

     nix-shell

  2. Configure and build:

     mkdir build && cd build
 cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=.... -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
 make

docs.title: APT-based
docs.text:
1. Install required dependencies:

     sudo apt-get install -y \
  build-essential \
  pkg-config \
  cmake \
  libglfw3-dev \
  mesa-common-dev \
  libglu1-mesa-dev \
  libgl1-mesa-dev \
  zlib1g-dev

  2. Configure and build:

     mkdir build && cd build
 cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
 make

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
I have not tested on macOS myself but the process should look something like this. I'm sure you'll figure it out :)

  1. Install dependencies using Homebrew:

     brew install cmake glfw3 ...

  2. Configure and build:

     mkdir build && cd build
 cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
 make

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To install the application (Linux users need to sudo if installing to protected directories):

make install

This will install:

  • Fonts to ~/.config/NanoCut/fonts/
  • Themes to ~/.config/NanoCut/themes/

docs.title: Running the Application
docs.text:
After building, you can run the application:

# From build directory
./bin/Release/NanoCut

# After installation
NanoCut

docs.title: CMake Configuration Details
docs.text:
The build system uses CMake's FetchContent to automatically download and build all third-party dependencies:

  • nlohmann/json v3.11.3 (JSON library)
  • Loguru v2.1.0 (logging library)
  • ImGui v1.92.6-docking (GUI library)
  • ImGuiFileDialog v0.6.7 (file dialog extension)
  • Mongoose 7.2 (web server/networking)
  • stb (header-only utilities)
  • serial 1.2.1 (cross-platform serial port library)
  • dxflib (local DXF parsing library)

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
CMake version too old:

CMake Error: cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.21)

Upgrade CMake to version 3.21 or later.

Missing OpenGL development packages:

fatal error: GL/gl.h: No such file or directory

Install OpenGL development packages for your distribution.

GLFW not found:

Could NOT find glfw3

Install GLFW development packages or let CMake download it automatically.

Compiler doesn't support C++20:

error: ‘std::format’ is not a member of ‘std’

Upgrade your compiler to GCC 11+, Clang 14+, or MSVC 2022+.

docs.title: Clean Build
docs.text:
If you encounter build issues, try a clean build:

rm -rf build
mkdir build && cd build
cmake [same parameters as the first time]
make/ninja/......

docs.title: Accessing Parameters
docs.text: Open the Machine Parameters dialog from Control View to view and modify machine settings. Changes are written to the controller immediately.

docs.title: Standard grbl Parameters
docs.text:
NanoCut firmware is based on grbl. The following standard parameters are available:

  • Machine extents: Maximum travel for each axis
  • Axis scale: Steps per unit (steps/mm or steps/inch)
  • Max velocity: Maximum speed for each axis
  • Max acceleration: Maximum acceleration for each axis
  • Homing settings: Feed rate, seek rate, debounce time, pull-off distance, and direction for each axis
  • Axis inversion: Reverse direction for individual axes
  • Limit pin inversion: Invert the logic of limit switch inputs
  • Probe pin inversion: Invert the logic of the probe input
  • Soft limits: Prevent the machine from moving beyond its defined extents

For detailed descriptions of all standard grbl parameters, refer to the grbl v1.1 Configuration documentation.

docs.title: NanoCut-Specific Parameters
docs.text: These parameters are specific to the NanoCut firmware and control plasma cutting behavior.

docs.title: Arc Voltage Divider ($33)
docs.text:
Calibration factor for reading arc voltage from the plasma cutter.

  • Default: 50 (1:50 voltage divider)
  • Range: 1--500

This value must match your hardware voltage divider circuit. The controller reads a scaled-down voltage from the plasma cutter and multiplies it by this factor to calculate the actual arc voltage. If your arc voltage readings are incorrect, adjust this parameter to match your divider ratio.

docs.title: Arc Stabilization Time
docs.text:
Time in milliseconds to wait after the torch fires before THC becomes active.

  • Default: 2000 ms

When the torch first fires, the arc voltage fluctuates as it stabilizes. This delay prevents THC from making unnecessary height adjustments during that initial period. Increase this value if you notice erratic torch movement at the start of each cut.

docs.title: Floating Head Backlash
docs.text:
Distance the floating head travels from its gravity rest position to the probe trigger point.

This compensates for mechanical backlash in the Z-axis probing system. When the torch probe touches the material, the floating head must travel through this backlash distance before the probe switch triggers. Setting this correctly ensures accurate touch-off measurements.

docs.title: Precise Jog Distance
docs.text:
The distance moved when using Ctrl+Arrow keys for precise jogging.

Set this to match your typical fine-positioning needs. Useful for accurately setting work zero or verifying clearances.

docs.title: Cutting Extents
docs.text:
Defines a safe rectangle within the machine extents where cutting is allowed. This provides a safety margin around the edges of the machine's travel. The safe cutting zone is displayed as a green rectangle in Control View.

Programs that extend outside the cutting extents will be rejected before running.

docs.title: Work Offsets
docs.text: Work offsets define the relationship between machine coordinates and work coordinates. Set them using the Zero X and Zero Y buttons in Control View. These offsets are saved automatically and persist across sessions.
